subject: Inventory properties via Assembly schema on bmcweb
commitMessage:
Inventory properties via Assembly schema on bmcweb

This commit implements Redfish Assembly schema on bmcweb.
This schema will be used to publish inventory data for FRUs which are
attached to a given Chassis and does not map to any specific schema
definition.

The properties which are published in this commit are LocationCode,
SparePartNumber, Model, SerialNumber and PartNumber.

One of the major use case to publish these properties via redfish
is for service engineers to identify the FRU and its location in the
system, which in turn will help them in repair/replacement related to
that FRU.

The validator has been executed on the change and no error has been
found.
As this has been tested on a development image some fields are empty
in the below pasted output for which warning was thrown by validator but
no errors.

Sample Output:
curl -k -H "X-Auth-Token: $bmc_token" -X GET https://${bmc}/redfish/v1/Chassis/chassis/Assembly/
{
  "@odata.id": "/redfish/v1/Chassis/chassis/Assembly",
  "@odata.type": "#Assembly.v1_3_0.Assembly",
  "Assemblies": [
    {
      "@odata.id": "/redfish/v1/Chassis/chassis/Assembly#/Assemblies/0",
      "@odata.type": "#Assembly.v1_3_0.AssemblyData",
      "MemberId": "0",
      "Model": "",
      "Name": "base_op_panel_blyth",
      "PartNumber": "PN12345",
      "SerialNumber": "YL6B85010000",
      "SparePartNumber": ""
    },
    {
      "@odata.id": "/redfish/v1/Chassis/chassis/Assembly#/Assemblies/1",
      "@odata.type": "#Assembly.v1_3_0.AssemblyData",
      "MemberId": "1",
      "Model": "",
      "Name": "lcd_op_panel_hill",
      "PartNumber": "PN12345",
      "SerialNumber": "YL6B86010000",
      "SparePartNumber": ""
    },
    {
      "@odata.id": "/redfish/v1/Chassis/chassis/Assembly#/Assemblies/2",
      "@odata.type": "#Assembly.v1_3_0.AssemblyData",
      "MemberId": "2",
      "Model": "",
      "Name": "tpm_wilson",
      "PartNumber": "PN12345",
      "SerialNumber": "YL6B59010000",
      "SparePartNumber": ""
    },
    {
      "@odata.id": "/redfish/v1/Chassis/chassis/Assembly#/Assemblies/3",
      "@odata.type": "#Assembly.v1_3_0.AssemblyData",
      "MemberId": "3",
      "Model": "",
      "Name": "vdd_vrm0",
      "PartNumber": "PN12345",
      "SerialNumber": "YL2E32010000",
      "SparePartNumber": ""
    },
    {
      "@odata.id": "/redfish/v1/Chassis/chassis/Assembly#/Assemblies/4",
      "@odata.type": "#Assembly.v1_3_0.AssemblyData",
      "MemberId": "4",
      "Model": "",
      "Name": "vdd_vrm1",
      "PartNumber": "PN12345",
      "SerialNumber": "YL2E32010000",
      "SparePartNumber": ""
    }
  ],
  "Assemblies@odata.count": 5,
  "Id": "Assembly",
  "Name": "Assembly Collection"
}

Signed-off-by: Sunny Srivastava <sunnsr25@in.ibm.com>
Change-Id: I2d462340fe1a0b0eb387697f0ff70fcafde3f8d9

Going to need more detail than this.
Sure, it was there just till the work was in progress. Will add details once it is review ready.

how are we linking the assembly to the chassis?
I don't see a check here. 
Do we need a new association ? E.g. item.vrm -> "chassis" -> item.chassis ?

Pending implementation at that point of time.
Now we are making DBus call to GetSubTree with object path of chassis as root path to check if these assemblies are linked to the given chassis.
GetSubTree returns an error if it can't find any elements in the subtree command, not sure this should be an error.
Did not get your concern here.

I'm sure these got copied from somewhere else but do these mean anything ? 
Can you add some detail here about assemblies? 

E.g. "The Assembly schema is the way to represent an inventory item in Redfish where there's not a more specific schema definition."
Done

Root path should not include system.

You need to actually search for the name of the thing you're looking for.  Also, please use the new object_path::filename() method to extract the filename.  Similar to this patch:
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/39157
You've forgotten to match up the associations to ensure that this entry is associated with the chassis in question.  Using the path hierarchy won't work in all cases.

Ed, are you saying we should be associating every inventory D-Bus object with its chassis using
https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/tree/master/xyz/openbmc_project/Association ? There was some concern that this could lead to a lot D-Bus objects

Is that the direction in general for OpenBMC? Trying to understand why it is wrong to rely on the object path hierarchy, when that is what a `bustl tree` would show.

> Ed, are you saying we should be associating every inventory D-Bus object with its chassis using
> https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/tree/master/xyz/openbmc_project/Association ? There was some concern that this could lead to a lot D-Bus objects
> 
> Is that the direction in general for OpenBMC? Trying to understand why it is wrong to rely on the object path hierarchy, when that is what a `bustl tree` would show.

Because redfish has multiple hierarchy.  Things like "contained by" "cooled by" "managed by" ect.  There's not a good way to represent all of those in a folder hierarchy, so in general, associations are needed, as they allows more flexibility in the code.

If we checked this in, this would be the only place that we use a multi-level dbus path hierarchy to determine the redfish paths.
Thank you Ed. The point about non-containment type relationships is very valid, associations would be the only way to represent those.
The id, name and related data shouldn't be added until after we've determined that this exists.  Otherwise the 404 behavior is incorrect.
Put this on line 193, and delete the res.end() on line 198.
Please pass shared_ptr's by value. This applies to all functions that take in a shared_ptr.

Passing them by value fails the CI, stating that const qualified member is copied for each invocation, consider making it a reference. (This warning gets treated like error in CI).
Also, we have similar implementation in another schemas where shared pointer is passed as const reference. like processor.hpp.
This could be done at the higher level function.
Done
Could you define this outside this for loop and capture it?
Done

How would one perform a reverse lookup with this ID for, say, driving an LED associated with this AssemblyData? I think this needs to match the last segment of the D-Bus object path of the Assembly inventory item.
Done

It is expected to be an index of the array, If we change that to last segment of Dbus object then validator will throw an error for index.

ERROR - This URI (/redfish/v1/Chassis/chassis/Assembly#/Assemblies/tpm_wilson) is accessing an array, but this is not an index: tpm_wilson
ERROR - @odata.id of ReferenceableMember does not contain a valid JSON pointer for this payload: /redfish/v1/Chassis/chassis/Assembly#/Assemblies/tpm_wilson

Look up can be performed using Member ID? Now that we have the last segment of Dbus Object assigned to it?
Why not a const ref?
Done
Set internal error to aResp here
Done
If this necessarily an error? Can't we return an empty array here?
Done
Shouldn't we return an HTTP error back to the client if the chassis ID is never found within this loop? I think it would be a 404?
Done
getAssembliesLinkedToChassis**, plural?
Done
Typo
Done
Please clean this space up.
Done
I don't think we should hardcode this to 0. How about id here? i.e. how about vdd_vrm0 here?
I think Sunny has fixed this in the latest PS based on the comment I gave earlier. This tested section needs to be updated.
Done

I am fine with this, but I don't think this is very useful either. 

Storage uses id for both of these.. 
https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/f23b729676559f539790580930b1ff3b0c05805b/redfish-core/lib/storage.hpp#L175

Does "Vdd Vrm0" make sense? I.e. replace the underscores with spaces?


PrettyName isn't used? I think that would be a great fit here
https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/32304979b404c24e32f195d08c667e65b9b34695/xyz/openbmc_project/Inventory/Item.interface.yaml#L5
Agree, Updated the field with PrettyName.
How about just "Assembly" here so it matches other resources in bmcweb? typically we set Id to the last segment of the URI.
Done
nit You can simplify it to the name of the variable. There is no need for (std::string(dataID). It is copied to callback when only name of the variable is passed
Done
nit No need to name it ec2 unless it increase readability
Is it ok that every member of "Assemblies" array has "0" in attribute "MemberId"?
Changed this to have name of the item. Like vdd_vrm0 or tpm_wilson. Taking it from the last part of DBus object path for the item.

This is a little bit wrong, name of the item should be assigned to "Name". "MemberId" is problematic because it has to be an index. According to scheme:
"This property shall uniquely identify the member within the collection. For services supporting Redfish v1.6 or higher, this value shall contain the zero-based array index."

MemberId needs to be unique, I guess name can be repeated sometimes, because you only take the filename from the received the path. Indexing has to start from 0.

You can create an atomic variable that indexes all received objects. The problem is that it is non deterministic solution across many requests. The perfect solution is that DBus objects have unique indexes across system.

Maybe I am wrong with above statements, so please, let me know what do you think. Thanks in advance

I have some queries here, 
-> Mandatory properties for AssemblyData under assembly schema is MemberId and odata.id. 
Now, odata.id expects the last value after "/" to be an index to the array. If I change that to something other than index, lets say name of the item, validator throws an error expecting it to be index to the array.

-> MemberId expects a string value. So we have change zero-based array index to string here.

a) As none of these will have the name of the item how de identify/patch individual items in this array? Or in a generic way "How do we patch individual items in array of referencable object?"
b) Also is it ok if none of the mandatory item holds the name of the item? 

Let me know if I am missing something out here.

I guess that MemberId is of type string because of the backward compatibility.

a) Here is a description about how to patch an array in Redfish:
http://redfish.dmtf.org/schemas/DSP0266_1.12.0.html#patch-on-array-properties
b) Yes, it is ok

As reference you can check following mockup:
https://redfish.dmtf.org/redfish/mockups/v1/1024#Chassis--Blade1--Thermal
It implements both: Name and MemberId in Temperatures list. It is similar to Assemblies list.

> I guess that MemberId is of type string because of the backward compatibility.
ok.

> It implements both: Name and MemberId in Temperatures list. It is similar to Assemblies list.
Ok, Though if I do a get on Thermal schema, the array of temperatures being populated are having memberId as "Ambient_0_Temp" and "PCIE_0_Temp". 
Also if I see the implementation of sensors.hpp I see memberId being filled with item name at some places.
Maybe they were implemented in older version of Redfish. If you still have doubts to use zero-based array index, you can direct those question to maintainers. Sorry for inconvenience.
Can all of them be done in doGet() based on return value?
Simply put, We will have to return codes from each method, and also we are following specific pattern in bmcweb so it has been done like this.
Why it is empty? I guess there should be a name of the interface

A GetAll with an empty interface parameter works, but of course it does not handle the case where a property name may be repeated across interfaces. I don't have a strong opinion here, but it looks like there is already code in bmcweb that does this (memory.hpp)

I take that back - looks like this would be violation of the D-Bus spec. Per https://dbus.freedesktop.org/doc/dbus-specification.html#standard-interfaces-properties:

" An empty string may be provided for the interface name; in this case, if there are multiple properties on an object with the same name, the results are undefined (picking one by according to an arbitrary deterministic rule, or returning an error, are the reasonable possibilities). "

So we should definitely fix this.
Modified, now the properties are fetched with respect to interface name.
I assume this is just a development build and these will eventually be filled in?
Yes, the FRU number keyword will be published as SparePartNumber of D-Bus.
Done
Chassis the assemblies are associated with reads better.
Typo: assemblies**
Done
Done

Typically the Id just matches the last segment of the URI.
Can this just be Assembly?
Done
Chassis
Done
typically we don't use auto here
Done

BTW, this is a great commit message.  It's clear, concise, talks through what you want to use this for, doesn't just reword what's already in the specification, but talks through the OpenBMC implementation.

Good job.
Ack

Considering the validator pushes warnings on empty properties, I find it really hard to believe that you ran it without any warnings popping up.  You might want to mention this in your commit message.
I have mentioned that in the patch set 33.
That looks wrong.  Might want to go debug.

The value was coming from DR keyword and was updated in interface as well.
Though now PrettyName concept is gone so will be the output.
Maybe instead using tempArray rename it to assembliesArrayJson or sth similar? Right now it is not a temporary array because it is a part of a response
Done
Use assemblyIndex here to improve readability, same on 33 line
Done

What if you don't have 
                "xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item.Vrm",
                "xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item.Tpm",
                "xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item.Panel",
                "xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item.Battery"
Mapper will return boost::system::errc::io_error correct?
Should we then return an empty array of assemblies ?
E.g. 
Chassis has a link to 
/redfish/v1/Chassis/<chassisId>/Assembly
But calling /redfish/v1/Chassis/<chassisId>/Assembly returns a 500 now if it can't find any Vrm/Tpm/Panel/Battery Inventory Items. This would be a validator error.

Please let me know if I am understanding it correctly.
You mean to say that there is entry in association json file but that inventory does not implement the interface or the inventoryPath does not exist at all?
This has been implemented in following patch sets

Since we are not making any change to this 'tempArray', hope capturing by reference here is not needed.
Same for line numbers: 142, 178

If reference is removed, it will be captured as constant copy, which will break the code at line 68-69.
Same applies for other instances as well.
Done
Please split this function up.  There are places that go to 10 scopes deep in a single method, which we should avoid where possible.

I did not do that because I don't see any other schema following that. So just to maintain consistency across implementations.
Included this api under namespace to distinguish it from being assumed as a general utility method.

This seems like something we should abstract and have in common with the chassis handlers.  There's already talk of removing board from this list, and I'd like to see it be somewhat common.

Where as here I am looping around all the chassis object that is found, implementing the interfaces.
Let me know I am understanding your comments correctly.
We're many scopes deep here.  Please clean this up.

The other 4 look reasonable, this one doesn't look right to me, as a backplane would likely be a form of board, which would "contain" drives.  We've also modeled backplanes as Chassis for some systems, so this would be changing that interpretation.  Lets remove it for the moment, move it to another patch and discuss.
Should we even care what the inventory item is if we have an association?

If we ignore the interface check then we will end up in DBus call failure, resulting in showing internal error in case any of the assembly association found in association json is not implemented. This check was for the purpose to ignore that in case the implementation is not found.

Though if we all agree in removing this check, I am ok with that.
I can make the changes post common consent.
I also think we might remove this. The association points us to the assembly inventory. might not bind the assembly schema with those five inventory types.
Generally we would use an association for this, as that's what we did with Sensors (also a chassis subsidiary.)  Lets not break that here.
I suspect this condition isn't needed.  Just pass through the empty list.
Sorting doesn't work here.  This implies that if a device gets removed, the other devices shift, which is incorrect.
This is an unordered list, why are we sorting it?

It was discussed in Discord that as member id is a zero based array index, we had a query that "What field in the PATCH request would we use to map back to a D-Bus object on the BMC?"
We came up with the solution of sorting the paths.

"Id" is rarely a fixed string.
It is when the last segment of the URI is hardcoded, e.g. /redfish/v1/Chassis/<str>/ThermalSubsystem/
Isn't this creating Assemblies for all Item.Chassis and Item.Boards?  That seems wrong.

This is how we do Power / Thermal / Sensors. And how PCIeSlots (up for review at https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/39970) does it. The links are there if no sensors / PCIeSlots / Assemblies are there it is just an empty array.
